awd_titl_txt: RUI: Solvation in Bulk and Confined Polyethylene Glycol
awd_abstract_narration:
Water (H2O) dissolves substances like table salt and sugar because the water molecules bind to the salt ions (sodium cations (Na+) and chloride anions  (Cl-)) or sugar molecules and therefore break up the solid lattice of these compounds.  Other liquids (alcohols, liquid ammonia and liquid carbon dioxide, and many others) can also dissolve chemical substances.  An interesting liquid whose solvation properties have not been well-studied is polyethylene glycol (PEG).  PEG is different from other common liquids because it is composed of long chains of carbon, hydrogen and oxygen atoms.  PEGs are nontoxic and have been successfully used as environmentally benign solvents in chemical synthesis, but we still do not know very much about their solvation properties. In this project supported by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms-A Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Markus Hoffmann, his undergraduate students at the State University of New York, College at Brockport, and international collaborators in Germany are generating new knowledge about PEG as a solvent.  Professor Hoffmann’s research program utilizes nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy, a technique related to the magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) tool used in medicine.  NMR spectroscopy provides information about the structure and motions of molecules, as well as interactions between molecules.  The Hoffmann laboratory also employs computer simulations of liquid systems.  Advanced NMR spectroscopy and computational studies are being done in collaboration with Professors Gerd Buntkowsky and Michael Vogel at the University of Darmstadt in Germany. Professor Hoffmann’s SUNY-Brockport students visit Darmstadt and conduct research there during the summer.  The Brockport students are therefore gaining valuable experience not only in the specific subject of the project, but also in international research collaboration.

The goal of the project is to develop an understanding of solvation in polyethylene glycol (PEG). To achieve the project goal, the thermophysical properties density, viscosity and self-diffusion coefficient of PEG solutions are being measured to verify force fields used in molecular dynamics (MD) simulations of the same solutions in bulk. Verified force fields are then used for MD simulations of PEG solutions in confinement in mesoporous silica pores with and without surface modification to develop an understanding of confinement effects on solvation and to explore the influence of pore surface modification.  The research team will interpret experimental data from several NMR spectroscopic techniques that probe dynamics and molecular interactions of PEG within the pore confinement. The NMR experiments include dynamic nuclear polarization (DNP) enhanced NMR spectroscopy; Solutes of interest include polarizing agents. The findings from the research have the potential to also impact many other research fields because PEGs and “PEGylated” compounds are widely used in pharmaceutical technologies to increase the lifetime of a drug in the circulatory system.  Additional broader impacts of the project include the training of undergraduate students, improving the infrastructure of research and research training at SUNY Brockport, and the addition of a meaningful international research experience for the students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Polyethylene glycol (PEG, H-[O-CH2-CH2]n-OH) is a mixture of ethylene glycol oligomers as illustrated for PEG200 in Figure 1. It is globally produced at about 600,000 tons a year to supply market needs for medical, personal care and industry applications. Lower molar weight PEGs such as PEG200 are liquid at room temperature. They are increasingly used as a solvent for chemical reactions because they can dissolve a wide variety of substances and are relatively inexpensive. Most importantly, PEGs are “green solvents” because they are benign for the environment and safe to use as they are non-toxic, biodegradable and have low vapor pressures, which reduces exposure through inhalation and results in low flammability. Therefore, there is a benefit to society when green solvents such as PEGs replace toxic ones (Figure 2).

At the beginning of this project, there was a lack of a molecular level understanding of PEG, which would be very helpful to facilitate conception of new applications of PEG as a chemical solvent. Even basic physical properties, such as density and viscosity were only limitedly available. Moreover, essentially nothing was known how PEG would behave under confinement, that is, when forced to be present in small dimensional cages. Such scenario occurs when chemical reactions require a catalyst, and that catalyst is attached to a high surface solid material, such as mesoporous silica material, to be able to easily retrieve the catalyst from the reaction mixture by filtration. While there is still much more basic research on PEG that needs to be done, the project outcomes listed below illustrate that this project made good progress. Important findings were made, some of which not only develop a basic understanding of PEG as a solvent but are of very practical consequence to advance its use in green chemistry.

Notable findings that are outcomes from this project:

  • The mixture composition of PEG200 does not vary significantly from vendor to vendor.
  • The physical properties of PEGs are only dependent on the average molar mass but not the composition.
  • The presence of water, the main impurity of PEGs, does not alter significantly its properties.
  • The physical properties of PEG can be predicted from the properties of the individual oligomer components.
  • The components of PEG200 do not cluster together but are spread evenly throughout.
  • There are significant intra- and intermolecular hydrogen bonding interactions present in PEG200 that need to be carefully considered for properly modeling the oligomer components.
  • PEG200 forms a glass rather than a crystalline solid when cooled, and the glass transition temperature significantly lowers when PEG200 is confined.
  • The surface decoration of mesoporous material greatly influences how PEG200 as well as related nonionic surfactants interact and align themselves with the surface. Additional solute molecules compete in these interactions.

These and other more detailed scientific findings were broadly disseminated in the peer-reviewed literature as well as presentations at conferences. Finally, some broader impacts should be noted as well. The new density and viscosity instruments purchased for this project were also used by other researchers to study aqueous polysaccharides. These studies were published in two journal articles. The research activities inspired incorporation of project-based experiments in the physical chemistry laboratory curriculum at SUNY Brockport. Most importantly, a total of thirteen undergraduate students of diverse backgrounds were involved in the project. As this project also involves a research collaboration with the research groups of Profs. Buntkowsky and Vogel at the Technical University Darmstadt in Germany, some of these traveled to Germany to participate in the research activities there. In addition to the valuable lab and research skills acquired while preparing samples, acquiring data and then analyzing and interpreting them, these students gained professional experiences with respect to cultural competencies. Some of the undergraduate students have graduated from SUNY Brockport and are now graduate student researchers, medical students, or employees. It is exciting to have witnessed these young individuals grow professionally. They are now making impactful contributions to society using their valuable experiences gained from participating in this research project.
